text: That's enough to jump up and down, cheer a lot (because everything is coming up roses) and buy the Sox Index. Not.
Machines and some traders know everything about price but very little about value, Divine. @hmeisler
There is nothing like price to change sentiment, Divine.
As I like to write, "Buyers live higher, sellers live lower." Just watch and listen: "You have to be long no matter what...." One would think the market was +300 points today.

My sense is that it is a hawkish cut with the body of the Fed possibly moving towards the policy of no more cuts (which should be a bit surprising to the markets) - baring an economic surprise/swan. But who knows? Maybe The Shadow knows. piped.video/watch?v=uMlRpN8A…

As reported on @realmoney I moved my long vol $s in $VXX into a larger short position in $SPY at $300.30. and $QQQ $191.98. Truly hate these volatility products with such tracking error and given contango (steepness between spot and futures). @jimcramer Good riddance!
@tomkeene
A hawkish cut is not market friendly - especially at current levels. My view. @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney
Josh I am more confident shorting the Indices than being long volatility given contango. So I moved long $VXX $s into short $SPY $QQQ
Out of $VXX at $23.50 - column on @realmoney Contango was too much of a headwind. @tomkeene @jimcramer

@realmoney Sep 18, 2019 | 02:10 PM EDT DOUG KASS Shorting the Post-Fed Ramp Since I conclude that, based on the Fed votes (coincident with the 25 bps cut), this will likely be the last rate cut this year, I have aggressively shorted the ramp post Fed announcement.

This could be viewed as market unfriendly. I added to (SPY) short at $300.30 and (QQQ) short at $191.98. @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @lizclaman @michaelsantoli @carquintanilla @riskreversal @guyadami @terranovajoe

growing concern), on top of the above, is the likelihood that the global economy will continue to deteriorate. Despite the weekend's attack on Saudi oil facilities, the price of crude oil is down again today -- for the second day in a row. And many oil company shares are giving

@realmoney Sep 18, 2019 | 01:43 PM EDT DOUG KASS Oil Vey! * I plan to continue to avoid energy shares * As I have for most of the last decade "If you own oils, I would scale them back. If they didn't move after the Middle East burned, I don't know what they will do if the econo

my keeps slowing. Seems hopeless." -- Jim "El Capitan" Cramer, Here's Why Oil Stocks Have Become Pariahs Many long-time subscribers may recognize that I have not owned an oil stock in years -- like more than five years! Not MLPs, integrateds, coals, nor exploration companies...

Analog. A MLB All Star baseball player (non pitcher) who went to majors out of high school as his goal to hit for a high batting average. But he has to look to the future and must invest wisely. He predominantly invests in stocks but knows nothing about equities and has

Goldman Sachs Asset Mangement do his investing. The player is interviewed in the media and is asked about his favorite market sectors and stocks. What is his market outlook he is also asked. He opines confidently without consulting Goldman or anyone else. Get the point?
Eggscellent.

Yes, Rev but my point is that they have limited knowledge @policy/marco and the subjects are outside of their sphere of knowledge - what is the value of their views on policy/macro? And if as I believe they are valueless and they base those valueless views on their mkt view -wtf?

Respectfully you didn't respond to my statement which referenced traders opining on macro and policy (without a knowledgeable background of the subjects) - I didn't say a word about predicting market movement Rev. Market views are like behinds, everyone has one.

Respectfully you missed the point which I know you know I was making. That is... If a short term trader has limited or no economic training or bona fide background on macroeconomic analysis or policy what is the value of their macro or policy views?
Come on now Rev.
@tomkeene

These might be dumb questions but: * Why should short term traders opine on macroeconomic forecasts and Fed policy? * Why should economists opine on individual stocks? * Why should technicians opine on fundamentals (and vice versa)? Why does everyone have an answer to every ques

tion asked? Why are everyone so confident in their answers even though many questions are outside their sphere of knowledge? Why aren the words, "I don't know" used more frequently? I don't know. thestreet.com/story/12451367… @tomkeene
